reviewText: Very sweet movie.  The actors all seem a little bit old for the characters they are playing but it doesn't matter.  To have that last road trip at the end of college with your best friends is something everybody wishes they had done too (or has the memories from actually doing it).  It's a definitive saying good-bye to boyhood and acknowledging they are men.  Bittersweet fun all the way to the end.

reviewText: I don't get the love for this little known pic. I thought it got off to a woefully slow start - in fact, I fell asleep - but then picked up a bit for the big parachute sequence. The hippy dippy pilot is repulsive, but entertaining. Then it bogged down again for the wedding sequence. I saw little to nothing that was comic here. The soundtrack is ok, but the Pat Metheny jazz fusion under the wedding sequence did not fit with the rest of the music which was period rock, and incorrect at that. Actually, Elton John's "Saturday Night's Alright for Fighting" came out long after 1971 when this picture is set. Otherwise, there is little to nothing to signify that this was 1971 in the picture. I was disappointed about that.
summary: Ok but a bit tedious at times
Title: N/A

reviewText: Five graduate college students, calling themselves the Groovers set out on their last road trip together to dig up Dom before going their separate ways. One a loner, one a ROTC, one confused, one a minister, and one passed out. Gardner Barnes played by Kevin Costner is the loner that will realize he should not have been so distant. Phil Hicks played by Judd Nelson is the ROTC that begins to appreciate life rather than constantly complain about it. Kenneth Waggener played by Sam Robards is confused about giving up a chance at marriage and whether he should show up for duty in the service. Dorman played by Chuck Bush studied for ministry but is not sure how to approach it. He finds that supporting those around him is the answer. Lester Griffin, played by Brian Cesak, is passed out for most their journey but will wake up just in time for their last night together. The directing, acting, sets, and music are all great.This movie was never a big hit, but it strikes a chord with most people that recall graduating from High School or College and spending a short time with their friends before going their own way. The journey in this case is to dig up a bottle not a friend. The journey is what makes this movie great because we realize that life is a journey and the trip is what makes it, not getting to the destination. Some scenes are hysterically funny like the Parachute School jump with pilot Truman Sparks played by Marvin J., McIntyre. Other scenes like the wedding are truly poignant. Don't miss the movie, it is one of Kevin Costner's and Judd Nelson's best. Fans of the 80s movies will definitely enjoy it. Although the timeline for the movie is 1971, the message is the same today. Life moves forward, so embrace it. The picture and sound quality on the DVD is excellent and it includes some extras. The soundtrack for this is wonderful if you are fan of rock and new age. Pat Metheny's "It's for you" is a nice touch.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is about moving on, becoming responsible with your life and putting aside childish things and becoming an adult.  It  is a phase that we all go through, and Fandango is last foolish road trip between 5 friends  before they grow up and become men.The 5 guys are apart of the Groovers,  a self-annointed group that acted like children throughout most of College.  Now that graduation is coming, one person is getting married, one wants to  make the military his career, one will become a priest and another will  join Arthur Andersen as an accountant.  Only Kevin Costner, in a magnetic  performance, refuses to grow up.They go on a road trip to find Dom and  to find themselves before they go into the real world.  Costner, hurt by  the woman who is marrying his best friend Sam, comtemplates his life with  the woman (played fetchingly by Suzy Amis) that is obviously the love of  his life.  It is funny that Judd Nelson plays a college graduate, and then  a year later plays a teenage punk (in the Breakfast Club).This movie  (whether knowingly or not) causes the viewer to casually review their youth  and all the foolishness that it is privileged to.  Many who look back at  that time with fondness will like this movie very much.  Those who do  not....well, you can relive it through this movie....Rating: B
summary: Disliked by Critics....I don't know why.

reviewText: Glad to see this on DVD.This is an excellent college coming of age type movie. Kevin Costner had some largely unnoticed early roles that deserved more recognition and this is one of them, Silverado being the other. He displays a great carefree happy go lucky attitude, with a wry wit thrown in. This is a good movie to this day and is not dated very much, just substitute going to Iraq, for the guys heading off to Vietnam. The scene with the Cadillac and the train is hilarious, as is the 'parachute sequence'. The whole movie is an engaging road trip!

reviewText: I'll admit, the first time I saw this movie I was skeptical and wasn't expecting much.  Boy, was I pleasantly surprised.  Fandango is one of the best movies I have ever seen and is the Genisis for such movies as "Dazed and Confused," "Fast Times at Ridgemont High," and ever movie in that genre.  Costner is excellent and the rest of the cast delievers above average performances in this end of college coming of age story.  You will want to watch it over and over again.  This movie literally has everything in it: parties, roadtrips, skydiving, weddings, love, heart aches, a crazy pilot, and of course, Dom.

reviewText: Kevin Costner always comes off best onscreen when he plays the bad boy who refuses to grow up, an archetype he played to acclaim in his star-making performance in Lawrence Kasdan's "Silverado" (1985), as well as his supporting turn in Mike Binder's "The Upside of Anger" in 2005. That's why his high-spirited charisma provides the chief pleasure in this forgotten 1985 coming-of-age road comedy. Granted, he is discernibly too old for the role of a rowdy University of Texas graduate who leads his four buddies, known together as the Groovers, on a no-holds-barred road trip across the expanses of West Texas before each goes their separate ways. However, the unwieldy combination of juvenile hi-jinks and dramatic undertones somehow manages to work, although I doubt if the testosterone-fueled antics will please everyone.Director/screenwriter Kevin Reynolds expanded a USC student film into an infectious study of beer-guzzling boys on the cusp of manhood in 1971 as the Vietnam War rages on half a world away. Costner is the smooth-talking slacker Gardner, while Judd Nelson is the uptight Phil more than ready to serve overseas and Sam Robards is the confused Kenneth who has regretfully decided to dump his fiancée Debbie when he is about to be drafted. Of course, complicating matters is the fact that Gardner has not gotten over his previous relationship with Debbie. All three young actors are quite good within the predictable confines of their roles. The story really amounts to their various misadventures, often amusing, especially the chaotic parachuting sequence, but all underlined by the irrefutable fact that this is their last hurrah as carefree carousers. There's a good use of period music in the background, though the best are the instrumental tracks from Pat Matheny which underline the emotional finality of the climax. The 2005 DVD only contains the original theatrical trailer as an extra.
summary: High-Spirited Costner Prevails Over Free-Wheeling Road Comedy with Serious Undertones

reviewText: Everytime I hear the word "fandango" this movie comes to mind. While its not my norm of entertainment I just cant forget the unforgetable Skydive scene, being a 15 year veteran with more then 1,000 jumps myself I find that one scene going over and over in my head just as it fueled my every trip to the drop zone when I was going through training in 1990! It is FUNNY!! (and very simular to a piolet we once had at Lake Elsinor - the funnest DZ west of the Mississippi!).While I don't remember much about the rest of the movie that one scene just stuck in my mind, and I saw it a few years before my own desicion to take up jumping, its just that memorable and that well done! Even funnier then Wesley Snipes 'first jump' in the movie "Drop Zone" (another well done movie and well worth mentioning!)FANDANGO!!Blue Skies everyone, see this flick!

reviewText: There are a only a small handful of films where I can honestly say that I literally burst out laughing, no exaggeration. Laughing so hard and so explosively that I thought my insides were about to tear from the effort; so hard that I literally had to stop the film and walk outside for a bit, calming down before starting up again.This is one of those films.And the weird part is that it's not really a comedy. Better known as a dramedy today, this drama with comedic elements is one of the most powerful coming-of-age films that I can think of when the theme is young men having to choose the path of their lives; to come to terms with the choices they've made, both bad and good, and to accept the consequences of those choices. Basically becoming men. (the other would be 'Breaking Away')Stars then-newcomers Kevin Costner and Judd Nelson, both of whom would find later success. And although the former is the more recognized name, it's actually Nelson whose performance I would categorize as more transformative, more crafted.Tells the tale of five friends on their final road trip. Having graduated college, Class Of 1970, they're enjoying the last days of youthful freedom, off to locate the last of their gang - Dom, who resides in Mexico - for one final party.The leader of their pack is Gardner, played by eventual Oscar winner Kevin Costner. He's the cool laid back alpha, the man with the plan. His casual disregard for everything and everyone is represented by an immature desire to constantly run away from any disruption of the good times. His opposite number is Phil, Judd Nelson's character; a by-the-book square who everyone knows is more talk than substance. His choice to serve in Vietnam, while admirable, is a cover for his insecurities and inexperience. Worse, everyone can see he's a scared kid in a man's body, totally ill prepared for the tasks ahead of him. Next is Kenneth, the good natured delta - Gardner's tail - wherever and whatever the alpha goes Kenny is sure to follow. Even if that road leads to disaster. And finally Dorman, one of the first modern incarnations of Silent Bob. A quiet behemoth who rarely utters a word but speaks volumes with a very large stick, literally.They're on their last trip, their final college adventure before going their separate ways. But it's not a life that Gardner wants to release. His immature Peter Pan mentality wants it to go on forever - even if it means ruining the lives of his friends. What is he willing to do? How far and what is he willing to sacrifice in the name of the good times? Choices made during the trip will decide if their friendship was ever genuine or just an excuse to hang out together.I bet, if you've actually read this far, you'll notice that the numbers don't add up. Only mentioned four dudes.Exactly.Watch the film. <wink> ;-DPersonal Note:- Again, if you've read this far, you'll recall I said this was, for me, one of the funniest films I have ever screened.That scene takes place at the rundown, beat-to-hell, jump school in the middle of nowhere. If anyone reading this is a veteran of the US Army Airborne, you'll understand why I nearly tore a stomach muscle from laughing so hard.After a very interesting thirty-minute training cycle - it's off to the drop zone.When his "instructor", who is not only high flying is also flying high, mentions in a deadpan shock: "Bummer. Hey, dude don't get upset man, but, uh... your parachute didn't open." Phil, who is plunging toward earth at 120 miles an hour, is understandably confused. Why? Because his primary was replaced and repacked with freshly washed clothes - Wile E. Coyote style. Just trust me."Go On" <rofl!> X-DDo yourself a favor and watch the movie from the beginning - don't cheat yourself out of this moment by searching for clips. It's worth it to understand the dynamics which drive Phil into the jump school in the first place. One of the strongest cases of a "double dog dare" ever.
summary: One Of The Best And Least Known Coming Of Age Films

reviewText: 'Fandango' is one of flicks you were sure to catch on HBO in the mid-80s - and if you didn't have cable you can be sure that you haven't seen of it.  Moreover, you can see a young Kevin Costner (before he was box office poison) and Judd Nelson (before he was box office poison).  Indeed, these are arguably the best performances you will ever see from Costner and Nelson.And even though it takes place in 1971, the basic premise is universal - one last trip with the boys in an effort to stave off adulthood.  The dramedy of errors yield some scenes that are both genuinely entertaining and comicly thrilling at the same time (particularly the sky diving scene, and when the characters attempt to 'catch' a train).The inner conflict among some of the characters - are the very crux that embellishes the razor thin plot.  Notably the smarmy Judd Nelson character.  'Fandango' adeptly intertwines comedy, dispair, sacfrice far more than one would imagine.  It truly is an excellent film - particularly since Hollywood rarely makes this types of film any longer.

reviewText: I absolutely LOVE this movie..it's  fun and even though there's a touch of very real seriousness beneath all the crazy stuff these guys do, it's a fantastic movie...it has everything, romance, real friendship, laughter, tears...love the last scenes with the wedding and how this whole dinky town and it's people help these guys pull it off...a little far fetched, but it still somehow seems believable...watch it..it's one of a kind..you'll really love the airplane pilot...and Kevin Costner is at his most gorgeous and has more energy than I've ever seen him have, he needed some of that energy in the Robin Hood movie he was in...and Judd Nelson is great...I think Hollywood cheated Judd...he's a better actor than most people give him credit for.  You will laugh and it will touch your heart.

reviewText: Differing from all typical formulas.  Five college friends cross Texas in an old Cadillac finding various adventures and laughs along the way.  Kevin Costner gives his loosest semi-comedic performance without so much stern reserve like his subsequent films.  The last 20 minutes is a pleasant surprise and it makes the first scene shimmer with life and meaning when you watch it again.

reviewText: Here's another youth film recommended to me because I'm writing a book on the subject.  Fandango is John Hughized by Kevin Reynolds seven years after Animal House defined frat life in the 1960-78 period.  Judd Nelson plays the rich kid with the Flounder like Cadillac to destroy on a road trip. Nelson is a nebbish, future Viet Nam bound Officer.  He's trying to improve his resume while fighting self-doubt and cowardice.  Weren't we all?I liked the Texas, Austin angle in Fandango.  Kevin Costner, thin and handsome with a drawling twang essentially propels himself to stardom in this vehicle as the worldly, cynical, fast talking frat boy leader.  Sam Robards is another Texas hunk who has dumped his girl at the alter although she had a fling with the Costner character sometime in the near past.  Suzy Amis looks pretty, but does not have one line in the film.These college films depict with comical exaggeration hedonistic behavior during the last period in youth where one can act like a child and it's rather expected.  So while mom and dad dream of the kid's future career as an accountant, the kid is drunk with his girlfriend on top of a pile of beer cans. Ah, those formative years.  The trouble is: films like Fandango are not about the choices of adulthood; these films glorify the unforgettable friendships of fleeting childhood, and that's what we old farts prefer to remember.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a hip flick! This is one of those low-budget, spontaneous films where all the actors look like they're having fun while making it. Kevin Reynolds did a nice job with the script, the setting, the desert scenery, and the filming. Kevin Costner & Co. are terrific and Marvin J. McIntyre is a riot! The part where he's scribbling all over the chalk board, trying to explain how to parachute out of an airplane is just hilarious. All five of "The Groovers" come from a different background. They all have different personalities, different plights, which makes things very interesting.  One of the boys is intent upon becoming a preacherman, another one is having second thoughts about getting married, while another one simply has no clue where he's going.  Judd Davis is anxiously awaiting his enlistment into the military and Vietnam, while Costner has been hanging around in College for several years trying to avoid the draft.  Despite their growing differences, they all decide to come together for one last fling before they go their own ways in life.  I loved the soundtrack to this movie as well! Los Lobos, Steppenwolf, Carol King, Blind Faith, etc. I think people of all ages, males and females, will like this film. Buy "Fandango" today and you'll be thoroughly entertained!Thanks
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of those movies that everyone should see, but few know about. A nostalgic comedy based in that era just before the end of the American involment in Nam that captures the fear of being sent there as a soldier and, at the same time, also captures that moment when the frivolity of youth comes to it's end and "real life" must now begin. This is a bitter-sweet tribute to these things, and a great comedic treatment of those relationships forged in the heady and wild days of higher education, frat-partys, and the girs we remember. This is a movie about friends and classmates on that last road-trip before the cross-road of life where friends must part for their own personal road. A salute to those of us who remember looking for "Dom".
Title: N/A

reviewText: I first saw this film in 1984. For many years I looked for other films by this director not realizing this was his debut. I must say his other films, when I found them do not live up to this special one. If he had made no other, Fandango, should go down in the annals of unsung masterpices. It never fails to please, suprise, and never, never has it disappointed me in viewing it multiple times. Many emotions are wrapped up in this film, including its time and place. Its wonderful use of music, the hyperreal texas landscapes and its beautiful cinematography all point to a labor of love. So all the best films are labors of love. Funny, touching, poignant and assured, this film should be savored.
